In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Georgia is aiming to improve the delivery of water supply and sanitation 
(WSS) services through effective implementation of legal, economic, and financial frameworks for 
local self-governance. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) interim operational strategy (2008–
2009)  for  Georgia 1  was  developed  in  line  with  the  government's  agenda,  and  identified 
development of the country's municipal infrastructure as a key contributor to sustainable economic 
growth, with the crosscutting themes of governance, regional cooperation, and environmental 
sustainability. Consequently, ADB's support to the WSS sector has grown since 2008 through the 
municipal services development project.2 
 
2.  The government proposes to improve and expand WSS services across urban centers by 
leveraging donor and private sector funds, and has requested ADB to develop an urban WSS 
sector strategy to assist it with planning long-term investments. It has also requested ADB to 
develop a regulatory framework and establish urban WSS tariffs to improve service delivery and 
ensure sustainability of WSS services. 
 
3.  ADB agreed with the government on the objectives and scope of the technical assistance 
(TA), the terms of reference for consultants, and the cost and implementation arrangements.3 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Access  to  services.  Water  supply  is  largely  based  on  groundwater  sources,  and 
abstraction  levels  are  high.  Nonrevenue  water  is  estimated  at  75%  or  higher  due  to  ageing 
infrastructure, with no replacement or rehabilitation investments made since the systems were 
constructed. The systems were designed for high supply levels to consumers—for example, Tbilisi 
supplies water at 800 liters per capita per day—with no emphasis on water conservation. Sewer 
systems cover parts of large towns (>50,000 persons), but there is no sewage treatment. Large 
parts of the population depend on pit latrines or septic tanks. Sewage is discharged into water 
channels and rivers, which affects downstream drinking water quality. Investments were prioritized 
and made based on the urgency of the requirement; consequently, the impact was not necessarily 
tangible  and  investment  sustainability  was  questionable.  This  also  has  health  implications, 
especially for vulnerable groups such as children and women. 
 
5.  Poverty and gender analysis. Field assessments in the country's urban sector indicated 
that the poor mostly live in areas without regular water supplies and sewage. They often suffer 
from  serious  water  supply  shortages,  poor  water  quality,  sewage  pollution,  and  poor  urban 
environmental sanitation. Poor hygiene and sanitation practices result in water borne illness and 
negatively impact the health of women4 and girls, who are primarily responsible for household 
water collection in these poor communities. The representation of women in management of water 
supply and sanitation services is low, while the potential to make decisions in the sector is high. 
Gender mainstreaming in the WSS sector is expected to enhance benefits to women through

6.  Environmental  management.  Four  river  basins  (Alazani,  Inguri,  Kura  and  Rioni)  are 
severely affected by direct sewage discharge from the towns. Lack of sewage treatment facilities, 
nonfunctional  sewage  treatment  plants,  and  dilapidated  sewer  systems  result  in  sewage 
percolation into the ground or direct discharge into surface water. Of particular importance is the 
sewage discharge into Kura River, which is an international waterway flowing into Azerbaijan from 
Georgia. Environmental management of the river through improved wastewater management in 
the riverside towns will specifically benefit downstream water abstraction and irrigation facilities. 
 
7.  Institutional  issues.  In  2009,  the  government  undertook  a  reform  path  to  correct 
institutional anomalies, and in June 2009, it consolidated 66 water companies in the country into 
three regional water companies—east, west, and Ajara (for the Autonomous Region). This decision 
was based on the recommendations of a United States Agency for International Development-
assisted TA to improve the sector's efficiency. In June 2009, the government also created the 
Water  Supply  Regional  Development  Agency  (WSRDA)  under  the  Ministry  of  Regional 
Development and Infrastructure (MORDI) to manage sector reforms and oversee the operations of 
the water companies. WSRDA is expected to cooperate closely with each regional governor's 
office, local government units, and the Municipal Development Fund (MDF) to develop the WSS 
sector.  
 
8.  Sustainable financing. Investments in the WSS sector started in 1996, with support from 
the World Bank. Investments are largely donor financed and approximately $350 million has been 
invested to date. Funds were channeled through the MDF with onlending to local governments, 
except  in  Batumi  where  the  German  development  cooperation  through  KfW  is  developing 
infrastructure directly through the local government. Cost recovery on investments is low, and 
billing to recover operational costs is lower than 50% in most towns. With the consolidation of 
water companies, the assets created through MDF and accrued liabilities by local governments are 
being transferred from local governments to the regional water companies.  
 
9.  External assistance. In addition to ADB, the World Bank, the United States Agency for 
International  Development,  the  German  development  cooperation  through  KfW, the  European 
Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development  (EBRD),  the  Swedish  International  Development 
Cooperation Agency, and the Millennium Challenge Corporation have supported the government's 
initiative to improve water and sanitation in urban centers. Focused and large-scale investments in 
the  sector  were  through:  (i)  the  Millennium  Challenge  Corporation,  EBRD,  and  the  Swedish 
International Development Cooperation Agency in the cities of Kutaisi, Borjomi, Kobuleti, and Poti; 
and (ii) the German development cooperation through KfW in Batumi. Support was primarily based 
on requests from the government and focused on improving the local economy in the target cities. 
ADB and World Bank support through the MDF covers the entire country and is focused on 
improving  priority  infrastructure.  EBRD  will  assist  the  regional  water  companies  in  corporate 
development, financial and operational performance improvement, capital investment planning, 
and capacity development. This assistance is expected to substantially improve service delivery 
and the fiscal status of the water companies. The World Bank also is conducting discussions with 
the government to develop a sanitation sector strategy for the rural sector and small towns. 
 
10.  Private sector participation. Tbilisi, Rustavi, Mskheta, and Gardabani water companies 
were privatized in June 2008 and are managed by a holding company—Georgia Water and Power

3
Company (GWPC).5 GWPC's annual turnover is approximately GEL100 million ($62.5 million) with 
90% of its income being sourced from the WSS sector; GWPC spends 75% of its income and 
generates a profit. The company proposes to use donor funds to finance the rehabilitation of 
Tbilisi's water supply system and the Gardabani sewage treatment plant (estimated to cost $90 
million–$150 million based on the extent of rehabilitation or reconstruction required). .  
 
11.  Reform agenda. The government has articulated its reform agenda in its Water Supply and 
Wastewater Sector Development Policy6. There is a clear emphasis on improving infrastructure 
and  service  quality;  cost  recovery,  financial  sustainability  of  regional  water  companies,  and 
operational efficiencies; demand management through reduced water losses; service access to the 
poor and vulnerable; a legal and regulatory framework; and sector management through modern 
management systems—management information systems and geographical information systems. 
WSRDA has commenced work on the above areas and is internally developing the consumer 
database and management information systems to improve revenue and expenditure management. 
Developing an urban WSS sector strategy will ensure that reforms address institutional, financial 
and environmental sustainability of services, and are oriented to meet the Government's long-term 
objective of improved WSS services across the country. 
 
12.  Regulation  of  WSS  services.  In  2009,  the  government  included  regulation  of  WSS 
services  as  a  core  function  of  the  Georgia  National  Energy  and  Water  Supply  Regulatory 
Commission (GNEWSRC). The GNEWSRC will regulate sector performance and currently plans to 
develop a legal and regulatory framework, and a tariff fixation methodology for the sector. The 
Water Law, 1997 needs to be aligned to the Reform Agenda to achieve independent, autonomous, 
accountable, and transparent regulation of WSS services. Amendments to the law are required, 
including those for implementing guidelines that focus on economic, technical, and environmental 
regulations. Similarly, a tariff setting methodology was approved in 2008 but requires revisiting 
given the inability of water companies to adopt proposed methods, which do not provide for a 
progressive method in transiting from O&M cost recovery to full cost recovery.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
13.  The  policy  and  advisory  TA  will  support  the  government's  ongoing  reform  agenda  by 
developing: (i) the urban WSS sector strategy and road map, including a social and gender 
development strategy; and (ii) the WSS tariff and regulatory framework. The outputs of the TA will 
also  facilitate  implementation  of  investment  programs  in  the  urban  WSS  sector,  including  a 
proposed ADB-financed multitranche financing facility investment program (MFF-IP).7 The TA will 
provide  direction  to  the  government  in  developing  a  strategic  vision  for  the  sector  and 
implementing its reform agenda. While developing the urban WSS sector strategy and road map,

the government will develop an investment plan and create a business climate for donors and 
cofinanciers to invest in the sector. Establishing the WSS tariff and regulatory framework will 
provide tools for regulating WSS services, and ensure investment sustainability in the long term. 
 
14.  The TA will also provide inputs to the MFF-IP along with a parallel project preparatory TA.8 
Analysis  and  outputs  of  the  TA  will  form  key  inputs—the  sector  strategy,  social  and  gender 
analysis,  financial  management  assessment  of  the  implementing  agencies  (WSRDA9 and  the 
regional water companies)—for structuring the MFF-IP. Results of the willingness-to-pay survey 
and tariff structuring will correlate with planned investments under the MFF-IP and will confirm the 
economic feasibility of proposed investments. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The  impact  of  the  TA  is  improved  WSS  services  in  Georgia's  provincial  capitals  and 
secondary towns. The outcome of the TA is improved governance and efficiently regulated WSS 
services in Georgia's urban centers. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The TA will result in the following outputs: 
 
(i)  Output  1:  Urban  WSS  sector  strategy  and  road  map. The TA will help the 
government  develop  an  urban  WSS  sector  strategy,  a  road  map  for  sector 
investments, and policy and institutional reforms, and thus help create a business 
climate for donor and private sector investments. The road map will also form the 
basis for ADB's MFF-IP. The TA will assess institutional, financial and procurement 
risks  associated  with  transactions  in  the  urban  WSS  sector,  and  develop  a 
management plan to mitigate the risks. 
 
(ii)  Output 2: Urban social and gender development strategy. The TA will help the 
government develop a poverty reduction and social strategy for the urban sector. 
The  assistance  will  also  result  in  a  gender  action  plan  to  ensure  gender 
development  and  participation  in  improving  WSS  services  in  Georgia's  urban 
centers. 
 
(iii)  Output 3: Urban WSS tariffs. The TA will conduct socioeconomic and willingness-
to-pay surveys for developing urban WSS tariffs. Tariff setting will draw from ADB's 
Economic  and  Research  Department  Technical  Note  Series  No.  23  on  Good 
Practices for Estimating Reliable Willingness-to-Pay Values in the Water Supply and 
Sanitation Sector, Economic and Research Department Technical Note Series No. 
24 on Utility Tariff Setting for Economic Efficiency and Financial Sustainability—A 
Review, and international best practices. Pro-poor tariffs will also be established. 
The framework and tariffs will be finalized after consulting relevant stakeholders, 
including GNEWSRC, WSRDA, and regional water companies. 
 
(iv)  Output 4: Urban WSS regulatory framework. The TA will develop an urban WSS 
regulatory framework for GNEWSRC and suggest amendments to the Water Law, 
1997.  The  regulatory  framework  will  be  based  on  international  best  practices,

17.  Outputs 1 and 2 will provide the government with a policy and strategic focus for developing 
its urban centers and ensuring social development in its provincial capitals and secondary cities. 
Outputs  3  and  4  will  provide  the  regulatory  body  with  guidelines  to  regulate  the  economic, 
technical, and environmental aspects of WSS services in the country's urban centers.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $884,500 equivalent.  ADB will finance $862,500 
equivalent  on  a  grant  basis  from  the  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–IV)  and  the 
government will finance the remaining $22,000 equivalent.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  For the policy and advisory TA, MORDI through the WSRDA will be the executing agency 
responsible for overseeing the delivery of outputs 1 and 2, while GNEWSRC will be the executing 
agency responsible for outputs 3 and 4. A financial management assessment of MORDI, WSRDA 
and regional water companies will be undertaken by the financial management specialist in the TA 
team. A procurement assessment of MORDI, WSRDA and regional water companies will be 
undertaken  by  ADB's  project  processing  team.  A  TA  steering  committee  comprising 
representatives of MORDI, WSRDA and GNEWSRC will coordinate outputs of the policy and 
advisory TA and the project preparatory TA. 
 
20.  A  firm  will  be  engaged  to  develop  the  sector  strategy,  road  map,  social  and  gender 
development strategy, WSS tariffs, and legal and regulatory framework. The firm will be selected 
through  a  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  using  simplified  technical  proposals  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
21.  A  team  of  international  consultants  (20  person-months)  and  national  consultants  (13 
person-months)  will  develop  TA  outputs.  Professionals  constituting  the  team  will  include 
institutional  development  specialists,  economists,  urban  and  regional  planners,  financial 
management specialists, social development and gender specialists, a regulation specialist, and a 
lawyer. The outline terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
22.  Time frame. The TA will be implemented from April through October 2010. An inception 
workshop will be conducted in May 2010, an interim workshop in July 2010, and a final workshop 
in September 2010. Final outputs will be available in October 2010. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $862,500 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Georgia for Developing an Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Strategy and 
Regulatory Framework for Georgia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overview 
1.  Multitranche financing facility loan and investment program. About $2 billion is required 
to improve the water supply and sanitation (WSS) services in Georgia's cities and towns (excluding 
Tbilisi and suburban towns). The Asian Development Bank (ADB) proposes to provide a loan for 
$500 million through its multitranche financing facility to improve the health of the resident population 
in  Georgia's  provincial  capitals  and  secondary  towns,  through  improved  water  and  sanitation 
services. This support will complement ongoing donor efforts to improve the country's urban WSS 
services. Through a separate project preparatory technical assistance (TA), ADB will develop a 
multitranche  financing  facility  investment  program  (MFF-IP).  The  MFF-IP  will  evolve  from  the 
government's vision for the sector based on its strategic road map, policy framework for the sector 
and reform implementation plan, and business climate for increased investments from donors. The 
policy and advisory TA consultants will work closely with the project preparatory TA consultants in 
developing the MFF-IP and helping the government implement its reform agenda. 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
2.  The policy and advisory TA will facilitate the government's reform agenda by: (i) developing 
the urban WSS sector strategy and road map, and a social and gender development strategy; and (ii) 
developing  the  WSS  tariff  and  regulatory  framework,  and  assisting  the  government  in  making 
corresponding amendments to the Water Law, 1997. 
 
  1.  Output 1: Urban WSS Sector Strategy and Road Map 
 
3.  Urban WSS sector strategy. Developing the sector strategy will include but not be limited to: 
(i) a review of existing studies, analyses, and policy frameworks relating to Georgia's urban sector; (ii) 
an  analysis  of  existing  water  and  sanitation  conditions  in  urban  centers  through  a  database 
assessment and site visits; (iii) an analysis of the competitive advantages and weaknesses and 
economic potential of each town, and an outline of the indicative economic development strategies 
for each town; (iv) a review of existing legal, regulatory, and planning frameworks for water and 
sewerage services, including associated legislation in various ministries including the Ministry of 
Environment and Natural Resources, Ministry of Economic Development, and Ministry of Labor, 
Health and Social Affairs; (v) a review of the investment plans of the regional water companies; (vi) a 
review  of  operational  plans  of  regional  water  companies,  including  technical  skills  required  for 
system maintenance; (vii) a review of institutional and financial relationships between the Ministry of 
Regional  Development  and  Infrastructure,  WSRDA,  the  Municipal  Development  Fund,  local 
governments,  and  regional  water  companies;  (viii)  an  examination  of  social  dimensions, 
environmental considerations, safeguards, and governance issues in sector management; and (ix) 
based on the above assessment, the development of a strategic vision for the urban WSS sector 
that would suggest improvements to the existing Water and Wastewater Sector Development Policy 
Framework.  
 
4.  Sector road map. Drawing from the sector strategy, the TA will develop a road map that will 
include but not be limited to: (i) a policy and institutional reform action plan; and (ii) an investment 
plan  for  infrastructure  improvement.  The  reform  action  plan  will  identify  activities,  institutional 
responsibilities and a time frame to address sector issues related to planning, core service delivery 
and asset management, institutional development, financial management, service delivery options 
including public–private partnerships, and legal and administrative frameworks. The investment plan 
will  draw  from  the  infrastructure  needs  assessment,  and  outline  the  sequencing  of  priority 
investments and indicate scope for public, private or public–private partnership financing.

10  Appendix 3 
 
  2.  Output 2: Social and Gender Development Strategy 
 
5.  The TA will help the government develop a poverty reduction and social strategy for the 
urban sector. The assistance will also result in a gender action plan to ensure gender development 
and participation in improving WSS services in Georgia's urban centers. The social and gender 
assessments and policies will be incorporated into the design of MFF-IP projects. 
 
  3.  Output 3: Urban WSS Tariffs 
 
6.  The TA will set tariffs for urban WSS based on the following goals: good governance, 
financial sustainability, distributive justice, economic efficiency, and fair pricing. Setting tariffs will 
involve a gradual approach, with the initial emphasis on financial sustainability and gradually being 
extended  to  encompass  broader  social  objectives,  including  economic  efficiency.  Tariff  setting 
principles will draw from ADB's Economic Research Development (ERD) technical notes, specifically 
drawing  from  ERD  Technical  Note  Series  No.  23  on  Good  Practices  for  Estimating  Reliable 
Willingness-to-Pay Values in the Water Supply and Sanitation Sector1, ERD Technical Note Series 
No. 24 on Utility Tariff Setting for Economic Efficiency and Financial Sustainability—A Review,2 and 
international best practices.  
 
7.  Tariff setting will include but not be limited to the following: (i) an assessment of trends in 
tariff resetting and principles governing decisions; (ii) a gender-disaggregated socioeconomic survey 
resulting in a social assessment plan3 to determine tariff affordability; (iii) a willingness-to-pay survey 
for WSS services; (iv) an evaluation of revenue and expenditure of regional water companies; (v) an 
assessment of capital expenditure and operational expenditure drawing from the investment plan in 
the sector road map; (vi) an assessment of operational expenditure subsidies transferred from local 
governments to water utilities,4 and of potential government subsidies, especially for wastewater and 
sewerage services; (vii) an assessment of the sector's ability to leverage carbon financing through 
energy efficiency measures and wastewater treatment options, and using such funds to determine 
tariff resetting; and (viii) an assessment of lifeline and pro-poor tariffs, the need for subsidies (output-
based aid), and practical measures of recovering costs. Tariffs will be developed in consultation with 
the GNEWSRC, WSRDA, and regional water companies. 
 
  4.  Output 4: Urban WSS Regulatory Framework 
 
8.  The TA will develop draft amendments to the Water Law, 19975 and implementing guidelines. 
The focus will be on economic, technical, and environmental regulation, to achieve the objective of 
independent, autonomous, accountable, and transparent regulation of water and sanitation services. 
The TA will include but not be limited to determining: (i) authority, functions, and tasks of the 
GNEWSRC,  its  institutional  and  organizational  structure,  and  its  relationship  with  government 
organizations  and  the  judiciary;  (ii)  GNEWSRC's  role  in  promoting  competitive,  transparent, 
accountable, and efficient conduct in service delivery; (iii) licensing requirements and procedures; (iv) 
regulation and monitoring procedures for tariffs and service levels based on performance targets; (v) 
incentives based on service benchmarking (to be developed under the TA); (vi) proper penalties,

enforcement, and appeals mechanisms; (vii) consumer rights, including handling of complaints and 
grievance redressal, and obligations with particular attention to the poor; (viii) responsibility of water 
companies6 to GNEWSRC, such as provision of information and audits; and (ix) public participation,

  5.  Outputs for the Report and Recommendation of the President 
 
9.  Under  the  TA,  the  firm  will  develop  the  following  appendixes  for  the  report  and 
recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors to facilitate ADB's approval of the MFF-IP: 
urban sector analysis, sector strategy and road map, financial management assessment of the 
executing agency (MORDI) and the implementing agencies (WSRDA and regional water companies) 
of the MFF-IP, and MFF-IP risk assessment and management plan. In coordination with the project 
preparatory TA consultants, the firm will develop financial and economic analyses for tranche 1 
project, and develop the summary poverty reduction and social strategy, and gender action plan for 
the MFF-IP.  
 
C.  Staffing Requirement and Scope of Work 
10.  The PATA will comprise 33 person-months of consultancy inputs, which will include 20 
person-months of international input and 13 person-months of national input. 
 
  1.  Team  Leader,  Economist  and  Institutional  Specialist  (6  person-months 
international and 1 person-month national) 
 
11.  The economist and institutional development specialist (Team Leader) will be responsible for 
coordinating inputs of all specialists and preparing all outputs under the TA. In addition, he/she will 
be specifically responsible for output 3: urban WSS tariffs under the TA, and economic analysis of 
tranche 1 project under the MFF-IP. The team leader will coordinate PPTA inputs through ADB's 
project officer for the PATA. 
 
12.  The  team  leader  will  conduct  project  economic  analyses  for  the  tranche  1  project  in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects,7 Guidelines for Economic 
Analysis of Water Supply Projects,8 Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of 
Investment Projects Financed by ADB (2002),9 Economic Analysis in 2002: a Retrospective,10 and 
Economic Analysis Retrospective 2003 Update.11 The team leader will (i) review the methodology for 
conducting economic evaluation with sensitivity analyses of the tranche 1 project; (ii) review detailed 
economic project costs and identify all project economic benefits, considering them with and without 
project scenarios, as well as incremental and non-incremental benefits; (iii) assess financial aspects 
of  the  water  demand  trends,  sanitation  requirements,  drinking  water  constraints,  and  growth 
potential and limitations; (iv) review the financial and economic aspects for the proposed alternative 
cost-effective technology options; (v) prepare feasibility estimates of the following cost items: civil 
works; equipment and materials; financial costs during construction; labor resources; maintenance 
and operation costs; and other costs; and (vi) conduct an economic viability analysis.

  2.  Urban and Regional Planner (4 person-months international and 3 person-months 
national) 
 
13.  The urban and regional planner will be responsible for developing the urban WSS sector 
strategy  and  road  map.  The  planner  should  have  an  engineering  background  and  substantial 
knowledge of sector issues related to planning, core WSS service delivery and asset management, 
institutional development, financial management, development of service delivery options including 
public–private partnerships, and legal and administrative frameworks. The planner is responsible for 
delivering output 1 and will: (i) review the database on WSS services in towns and cities across the 
country; (ii) conduct a thorough analysis of demography, economy, and development in the region 
and urban centers; (iii) determine the impact on existing infrastructure and the region; (iv) review 
plans of regional water companies for infrastructure improvement; (v) review and collate the roles 
and responsibilities of institutions that regulate or manage urban growth and services, and identify a 
suitable institutional and regulatory framework for regulating growth in the region; and (vi) develop 
the sector strategy, road map, and the investment plan for developing WSS services in the country. 
Along with the team leader, the planner will conduct workshops to disseminate findings and collate 
stakeholder views for discussion with the government and to finalize the strategy and road map. 
 
  3.  Social  Development  Specialist  (3  person-months  international  and  4  person-
months national) 
 
14.  The social development specialist will be responsible for preparing the social and gender 
assessments, and for developing the appropriate social and gender policies that will be incorporated 
into the project design of the investment program projects. The tasks of the social development 
specialist will include, but will not necessarily be restricted to, the following: (i) following ADB's 
guidelines in the Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis12 make field visits to selected project 
sites, and together with the resettlement specialist conduct a gender-disaggregated socioeconomic 
survey of the population in the project locality, including health indicators; conduct interviews, focus 
group discussions with the target population of the projects and relevant key stakeholders, including 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), especially regarding women's involvement in the project as 
major stakeholders on the consumer level; prepare a gender-disaggregated socioeconomic profile; 
undertake poverty mapping and analysis; undertake an analysis on access to basic facilities, health 
and sanitation conditions; and prepare explicit gender and labor profiles and analyses;13 (ii) assess 
the socioeconomic benefits of tranche 1 project and its possible negative impact on gender; (iii) 
collect gender-disaggregated data, prepare the gender profile of the target population of the selected 
project  area,  and  identify  (a)  constraints  and  opportunities  for  women’s  participation  in  project 
planning and implementation, and (b) training requirements through focus group discussions; (iv) 
undertake a review of current institutional arrangements and determine the role and responsibilities 
of  relevant  agencies  (including  women's  NGOs)  dealing  with  the  enforcement  of  women's  full 
participation in the water and sanitation sector; (v) conduct a social and gender assessment and 
analysis by obtaining data on (a) women’s and men's access to land, markets, and employment 
opportunities, and (b) gender dimensions of their access to social infrastructure and services (e.g., 
health and hygiene, literacy program), and then assessing the likely impact of all these aspects on 
project activities; (vi) undertake a sex-disaggregated analysis of the population's health status; (vii) 
based on all the analyses above, work closely with the MFF-IP TA team to develop program design 
elements that address social and gender issues; (viii) recommend poverty reduction strategies; (ix) 
prepare a stakeholder analysis framework; (x) prepare an overall framework for the participation of 
community based groups (including indigenous peoples) and NGOs; (xi) prepare a gender action

plan; (xii) prepare a labor plan; and (xiii) prepare a summary poverty reduction and social strategy 
for the MFF-IP. 
 
  4.  Financial  Management  Specialist (4 person-months international and 2 person-
months national) 
 
15.  The financial management specialist will (i) review and assess the financial performance of 
regional water companies by examining budgets and financial statements, and prepare pro forma 
financial statements of regional water companies and link them to project cash flow and fiscal impact 
analysis in order to assess the financial viability of the proposed tranche 1 project; (ii) review cost 
recovery policies and tariff levels in tranche 1 project; (iii) prepare financial projections for operations 
10 years after project completion; (iv) compute relevant financial indicators of tranche 1 project to 
assess its financial viability; (v) prepare project cost estimates; (vi) examine feasible cost-recovery 
approaches to ensure full operation and maintenance (O&M) and sustainability of investments; and 
(vii) conduct financial sustainability analysis, and develop the financial improvement action plan. 
 
16.  The specialist will (i) conduct a financial management assessment of the executing agency 
(MORDI) and the implementing agencies (WSRDA and regional water companies) that will include a 
review of (a) corporate planning and budgetary controls, (b) financial and management accounting 
and reporting, (c) internal control and audit systems, and (d) data processing; (ii) identify any 
financial management issue that would affect project implementation and/or sustainable operation of 
project investments, and suggest mitigation strategies to be incorporated either into project design or 
project implementation arrangements; (iii) suggest appropriate financial covenants to monitor the 
Project’s financial performance; and (iv) prepare a financial management internal control and risk 
assessment  of  the  executing  agency  (MORDI)  and  the  implementing  agencies  (WSRDA  and 
regional water companies), identify material differences and actions needed to mitigate risk, and 
propose practical recommendations for improving financial management functions and staffing for 
financial operations.  
 
17.  The financial analysis and financial management assessment should include reference to the 
Financial  Due  Diligence  Methodology  Note  2009  and  the  following  references:  (i)  Second 
Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan (GACAP II) Guidelines;14 (ii) Sourcebook: Diagnostics to 
Assist Preparation of Governance Risk Assessments;15 and (iii) Financial Management and Analysis 
of Projects Guidelines.16 
 
  5.  Regulation Specialist (3 person-months international) 
 
18.  The regulation specialist will be responsible for developing the regulatory framework for 
GNEWSRC and assisting the government in amending the Water Law, 1997. The specialist will be 
responsible for outputs 3, with the Team Leader, and for output 4 and will (i) review existing laws 
and statutes for the sector along with the national legal specialist; (ii) develop benchmarks for WSS 
service delivery based on the current and proposed performance of regional water companies; (iii) 
develop  performance  standards—incentives  and  penalty  schemes—for  water  companies;  (iv) 
develop  a  complaint  redressal  mechanism;  and  (v)  suggest  amendments  to  the  water  and 
wastewater development policy, and Water Law, 1997 based on the above assessment.

  6.  Legal Specialist (3 person-months national) 
 
19.  The legal specialist will be responsible for reviewing all laws related to the sector, including 
those issued by the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources, the Ministry of Economic 
Development, and the Ministry of Labor, Health and Social Affairs. Based on the review, the legal 
specialist should advise on the legal implications of sector development and suggest methods to 
enforce legislation. In consultation with the team leader/economist and the regulation specialist, the 
legal specialist should develop the regulatory framework, and suggest amendments to the Water 
Law, 1997 and the WSS policy framework.
